headline.main: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.15 percent and that on the six-month bill was 5.38 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE chance to purchase a home with a maximum down payment of $2,500 will be one of the attractions of a home-buyers' fair on May 10 at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale. The fair will be sponsored by the New York office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. The offer comes in the form of a certificate available only at the fair and only to a buyer who agrees to purchase a home with a Government-insured F.H.A mortgage and to occupy that home. Such loans usually require a down payment of 3 to 5 percent of the sales price. Regular mortgages usually require a down payment of at least 10 percent.

headline.main: HUD Fair Offers Low Down Payments on Its Houses

docs.abstract: Home-buyers' fair on May 10 will be sponsored by New York office of Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development; people attending fair will be offered chance to purchase home with maximum down payment of $2,500, if they agree to purchase home with Government-insured FHA mortgage and to occupy that home; photos (In the Region/Long Island) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If buildings could shiver, this Camden, N.J., tenement would have the shakes. It is a February morning too cold for words. The parking lot is a moonscape of craters and ice, and what was once a buzzer is now another crevice for the Arctic wind to exploit. That leaves Kathryn Edin stranded below a kitchen window, announcing her arrival with a shout. She is indefatigably cheerful.
docs.abstract: Jason DeParle profile of Kathryn Edin, unusual poverty expert who does field interviews with welfare mothers; discusses her findings that many families on welfare suffer privations even though most have some unreported income; she notes that women taking entry-level jobs need some family help to be able to work and are even more likely than those on welfare to be unable to pay their bills; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: What a dazzling array of ideas and proposals make up today's extravaganza in Philadelphia called the Presidents' Summit for America's Future! Americans helping Americans out of a deep compassion for the disadvantaged, especially the 15 million children at risk. ''A new way of doing business'' (in the words of the summit meeting's organizers) that will, by the year 2000, give at least two million of these children better health, better education, a better chance at a good job, safer places to live and work and even better relationships with their parents or mentors.
docs.abstract: Former Gov Mario M Cuomo Op-Ed article on bipartisan effort led by Pres Clinton for volunteer program to aid children; urges Congress to continue funding needed social services programs, holding they cannot be replaced by private philanthropy; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate's Republicans are moving swiftly to consider a series of far-reaching measures designed to bolster their influence in selecting Federal judges and to inhibit President Clinton from naming anyone not to their liking. Under one of several proposals to be considered by the Republicans at a caucus on Tuesday, a small number of Republican senators would have the power to block any Clinton Administration nominees they thought were not conservative enough or were unsuitable for any other reason.

headline.main: REPUBLICANS SEEK GREATER INFLUENCE IN NAMING JUDGES

docs.abstract: Senate Republican caucus to weigh procedural changes drafted by Sen Phil Gramm that would for first time give senators kind of veto power over nominees to nation's 11 Federal appeals courts; one proposal would require Republicans on Judiciary Committee to block Pres Clinton nominee opposed by majority of Republican senators from states in circuit; traditionally, senators are able to exercise authority only over nominees from their home states to lower level Federal District Courts, where judges have little ideological leeway (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate's Republicans are moving swiftly to consider a series of far-reaching measures designed to bolster their influence in selecting Federal judges and to inhibit President Clinton from naming anyone not to their liking.    Under one of several...

docs.lead_paragraph: As lawmakers across the nation struggle to find ways to offer affordable health care coverage to millions of uninsured children, New York's rapidly expanding program for subsidized health insurance is attracting national attention and some scrutiny. The program, Child Health Plus, insures children whose parents are between jobs or have jobs that offer no health coverage; whose families have assets or incomes too high for Medicaid coverage but who cannot afford commercial insurance, or whose status as illegal immigrants does not allow them to get most government benefits.

headline.main: New York Health Insurance Plan for Children Draws Wide Attention

docs.abstract: New York's Child Health Plus program of subsidized insurance draws national attention as model of type of coverage proposed under bipartisan Kennedy-Hatch bill; New York program insures children whose parents have no jobs or jobs without coverage, whose families have incomes too high for Medicaid but too low to afford insurance, as well as illegal immigrants; family of four with income up to $35,000 would be eligible; New York is now adding hospitalization and, for first time, requiring contributions and $2 payment for doctor visits; advocates fear recipients will drop out rather than pay anything; graphs profiling recipients and costs (M)
docs.snippet: As lawmakers across the nation struggle to find ways to offer affordable health care coverage to millions of uninsured children, New York's rapidly expanding program for subsidized health insurance is attracting national attention and some scrutiny. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME days it seems like every other driver in Lane 2 is lost. ''I want to go back to the New Jersey Turnpike,'' a man in an RV with Quebec plates said to Walt Barber moments after Mr. Barber had stepped into his booth at the Raritan South Toll Plaza on the Garden State Parkway. ''I made a mistake.''

docs.lead_paragraph: SO, you're 15, invincible and thinking of starting to smoke. Maybe you've tried it a few times, out behind school. It's cool, and your friends are doing it, too. Oh, yes, some tireless adults needle you about how it will kill you some day -- for every three teen-agers who start smoking, they drone on, one will die from it. But, hey, that can't happen to you.
docs.abstract: Breakdown of high economic cost of smoking habit over lifetime; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To understand some of what lies behind President Jacques Chirac's decision to risk his conservative Government's political future on early national elections, it helps to talk with Bernard Jorant, a 46-year-old long-distance truck driver who lives in Le Mans, in the heart of France. Mr. Jorant and tens of thousands of other truck drivers tied up highways across the country for a month last winter in a strike aimed at the core of the Government's budget cuts.
docs.abstract: Polls show that Pres Jacques Chirac and Prime Min Alain Juppe, who have gambled by calling early national elections in France, may win re-election of their coalition, though probably with sharply reduced majority, despite their extreme unpopularity; victory would give them five more years to contine tight-budget policies; voters are beginning to take seriously warnings that Europe cannot continue to fund early retirements and other social benefits (M)
